text: The FIRST MATE yells into the radio, their only hope:

Mayday! Mayday! This is fishing ship "Annabelle"! We're floundering and taking on water! Mayday! Mayday! An enormous WAVE smashes against the bow of the ship, throwing everyone in the cabin off balance. A glass shatters. The Captain enters, the two lock eyes: it looks bad.
What's our position?
(grim) I don't know.
If you don't know where we are then you don't know where we're going!! You could be running us right into the rocks!! Then: a VOICE breaks through the static on the radio.

Coast Guard Portland Station to Annabelle: Do you read me? As the mate starts to answer, lightning STRIKES the huge mast. It CRASHES through the pilothouse window, SMASHING radio. Glass, radio parts FLY. The Captain's shoulders slump: now they're done for.

The Captain comes out on deck: his men stare at him, eyes full of fear, desperation. Then, impossibly... the WINDS TRAIL OFF. In seconds, the sea flattens into a sheet of glass. All is DEAD CALM. It's eerie. Ropes CREAK. The men ERUPT in celebration, CHEERING, hugging each othe it's over! The angry Captain YELLS:
It's not over, you idiots! It's just the eye of the storm! The men look around: far off on the horizon, the raging storm still surrounds the ship... but overhead, stars appear. It's eerie, strange.

Look! Overhead, a new, brilliant star appears... and it's quick growing larger. The blazing light speeds toward the startled sailors, impossibly fast, intensely bright, blinding, all goes white... KAWHOOSH! The light CRASHES into the sea. Water flies, th sea BOILS, CHURNING, ROARING, the water green-lit from below. Great clouds of steam BILLOW and HISS. Then, without warning, the raging storm ROARS back with a vengeance, a huge wave SLAMS into the ship. Again the fishermen fight for their lives. But then a dim light appears, far off in the rain: a bare visible beam sweeps back and forth in the storm.

The lighthouse! Head for it! The desperate men struggle to steer their limping ship toward the light. Then, CLANG! The ship shudders, stops instantly: the ship has SLAMMED into... a wall! A solid wall, a wall made of... iron?  3. The sailors freeze, speechless: they look up the wall, up up... flashes of lightning illuminate: a face! Twin beams of light comes from what look to be... eyes, in an enormo face. A giant?! Made of metal! THUNDER BOOMS. The impossible face seems to turn downward... and looks at the men. The men quake. A HUGE WAVE CRASHES over the ship and throws the men overboard, into the sea. The ship begins sinking fast.

head_text.subj: IN THE WATER, NEAR THE CLIFFS

text: Men surface, cling to ship debris. Two men in a lifeboat pull their comrades from the chill waters. A wave WASHES over rocks, leaves behind a limp fisherman, clinging to the rocks. Barely alive, whipped by wind and rain, he sees lightning-brief glimpses of the giant thing it moves off in the HOWLING storm and dissapears. The VIEW MOVES up, up the rocky cliff to the lighthouse perched atop the cliff. The brilliant beam tries in vain penetrate the RAGING storm...
We push through the storm towards an upstairs window, and into...
A flashlight beam illustrates the STORM SMASHING against window.

head_text.subj: AS THE STORM RAGES, HOGARTH EXPLORES HIS ROOM BY FLASHLIG
MEMORABILIA, THE WINDS HOWL GROWS LOUDER.

text: GLASS SHATTERS and a cold wind whips into the room.
Hogarth....?!! The door flies open and Hogarth's mother ANNIE is there. Late twenties, attractive.
Are you alright, honey?

Yeah, Mom, I'm okay... Annie turns to the shattered window pane, then pushes Hogarth's bookshelf in front of it to block the wind. Hogarth stares at his monther. She looks spooked. HOGARTH (CONT’D) ++. are you?
I hate when the power goes out. But... yes, I'm fine. Outside, the wind howls.
Wanna stay up with me for a while? (coaxing) I could tell you a story... Annie smiles, touched.
A story, huh? What have you got for me this time?

Well, it's a story about... Hogarth scans the toys and souvenirs on his bedside table With a sudden flash of inspiration, he grabs a baseball card. HOGARTH (CONT’D) Mickey Mantle. He had a magic bat, Mom. Everybody says so. As Annie watches Hogarth with motherly adoration, Hogarth picks up a plastic dinosaur. HOGARTH (CONT’D) Anyway, this is the story of Mickey's adventures with the stegosaurus. It's got action and romance. And the best part is, it's all true. Annie laughs and touches a fingertip on Hogarth's forehea
You've got a lot going on in there, don't you, Hogarth? (MORE )

(wistfully) Just like your father... For a moment Hogarth beams. He looks over at a framed pho that sits on his nightstand, that shows a handsome man dressed in an army uniform. And as he stares at the photo a sad, pensive look comes over Hogarth's face. Annie sees it.
I can't wait 'til he comes back.
(gently) We've been through this before, honey...
They found his plane, mom. They didn't find him. He's gonna come back. Annie sees the resolute look in her son's eyes and decide to change tack.
So what could he do with that magic bat of his?
h (lost in thought) Huh?
Mickey Mantle. Could he cast spells with it, like a magician?
Oh... (brightening) Yeah. Yeah that's exactly what he could do. And that's why he was known as the Wizard of Sherwood Forest.
(amused) Sherwood Forest, huh?
Right. And then one day, this Stegosaurus shows up. And he says--— (deep voice) (MORE )
"Who thinks he is mightier than me, the mighty thunder lizard?"
And this is all true, now?

Every word, Mom -- I wouldn't make this up. So Mickey says, "I'm the two time American League batting champ. I was MVP of the All-Star game three times running. I go anywhere I please in this forest..." We DRIFT BACK from mother and son, hunkered down in a poo of warm flashlight, surrounded by darkness...

The sun has risen on a beautiful Maine morning. The camera starts HIGH in a tall tree, where a bird is repairing its storm-damaged nest, and pans down from this literal bird's-eye view to the streets of Rockwell, where stoic New Englanders are doing repairs of their own. Down the middle of the street comes Hogarth, on a bike. I the wire bike-basket in front of him is a shoebox with ho punched in the lid. A couple of LOCALS are clearing a felled tree. We hear th conversation as they drift across the screen in Hogarth's travelling POV.
Strangest storm I ever seen. Swept away my best iron wheelbarrow. But left the handles behind... Now Hogarth passes a pair of WOMEN who gossip as they rak up leaves and branches.
My husband spoke to one of those fishermen this morning. Fellow wouldn't talk about the shipwreck at all. Said we'd all think he was mad.
Now what do you think he meant by that?
Well, I'm sure I don't know. (lowers her voice) But it wouldn't surprise me if the communists are involved.

The "Chat ~n-¥ Chew" diner sits near the docks and the to square: the center of all social life in the village. Hogarth arrives, at last, and parks his bike. He takes th shoebox out of his bike basket, opens it a little and spe to whatever is inside.
Remember -- be charming.

The diner is packed. EVERYBODY is here--FARMERS, FISHERME - all swapping storm-stories. It's LOUD. And there's no empty table, no place to sit. Hogarth enters and looks around. He spots Annie, now dressed as a waitress and serving coffee from behind the counter. Hogarth puts on a big smile and waves at her.

Hey, Mom! You won't believe our good luck! Look what I found... He makes his way through the coffee shop to the counter. he passes by, various local ladies -- THE BUSYBODIES -- l up from their breakfasts, mouths downcast and eyes half- lidded -- ever ready to cast judgement, should the precio opportunity arise. Hogarth arrives at the counter opens the shoebox for Anni A baby squirrel pokes its head out. Annie rolls her eyes. HOGARTH (CONT’D) His tree musta gotten knocked down in the storm! Can I keep him?
Hogarth, we've been through this. No pets...
But he's not a pet, Mom. He's a friend. You're always saying I should have more friends come over, right? Well now I've got one. (selling it) (MORE )
You gotta admit I'm making sense here.
Hogarth, if there's one thing we've learned from your many pets, it's that claws and furniture do not mix.
I know but--
No "buts." We have got to rent a room this year if we're going to make ends meet... Nearby a Busybody perks up her ears, elbows her neighbor, and raises her eyebrows significantly.
.»..and no one wants to live ina place with shredded upholstery.
You'll never know he's there. I'll keep him in a cage--
-until you feel sorry for him and "set him free" in the house. Remember the raccoon, Hogarth? God, I remember the raccoon...
Please, mom. At least look at him...

(softening) Alright, where is this guy...? Hogarth grins and reaches down for his box... then notice there's nothing inside it. The squirrel has escaped. Hogarth looks back at Annie, hiding his desperation.

I... will go get him... okay? Hogarth turns, his eyes darting around frantically. Final he spies a FURRY TAIL disappearing under a four-person ta with a single occupant, hidden behind a newspaper.  HOGARTH (CONT’D) Excuse me...? Excuse me... No response. Behind the paper, smoke rises. HOGARTH (CONT’D) Sir? Still no response. Hogarth is getting exasperated.

Sir...? Sir? Sir! EXCUSE ME, S-- Hogarth STOPS with sudden realization. He slowly pushes d the top of the paper, revealing that the person he's talk to ... ...is ASLEEP. A lit cigarette with an impossibly long ash dangles precariously from his lips. This is DEAN McCOPPEN sporting sunglasses, handsome in a rumpled sort of way. Unshaved, uncombed, unusual. A beatnik. Here. Hogarth's heard of them, but this is the first one he's seen up clo The beatnik's head lolls... ...and his cigarette drops in his lap. He WAKES.
I was snoring, right? Sorry, man. I'm just not a morning person...
Please don't move, sir. My pet's under your table--don't look--if you make a scene my mom won't let me keep him.
Don't worry sonny, I'm cool as a cucumb- (SHRIEK OF PAIN)
He LEAPS up, HOLLERING, SLAPPING at his smoking pants.
as she turns to watch the COMMOTION from across the room. The busybodies are all abuzz. Who is the weird guy with Hogarth?  10.
as Dean finally gets under control. He looks around. The whole joint is staring at him. He picks up his cigarette butt and holds it as he addresses the other diners.
Had a little cigarette mishap. It's under control. Show's over. Cool yourselves and resume breakfasting, people. (sitting, to Hogarth) What kind of pet, kid?
A squirrel. Don't worry, he's friendly.
Is my son bothering you, sir? Dean stares at Annie, smiling strangely.
Yes. No. Call me Dean. As Dean and Annie size each other up, the three Busybodie whisper cattily back and forth.
Oh! I don't know why they let such people in here.
She ought to ignore him.
You forget how single she is, dear. The busybodies exchange smug, catty grins.

The camera is very low, as an official-looking car pulls and comes to a stop in front of us, its front grille fill the screen. The words "U.S. GOVERNMENT" are printed boldl across the top of the license plate.

And the driver's side car door opens. A well dressed man his mid-thirties, KENT MANSLEY, steps out, puffs on his p and surveys his surroundings with a steely-eyed, square- jawed gaze.  11. Now a troubled look comes over him, as he notices the US COVERNMENT decal on his car door is peeling off. He press it flat -- it curls up again. He presses it flat -- it curls. He licks his fingers, rubs it on the decal and presses it hard -- and it holds. Kent's look of confidenc returns. He slams the car door with authority; one side o the license plate unhinges and hangs at an angle. Kent si with defeat, and walks away.
Annie speaks gently to Hogarth.
Hogarth. I thought you were getting your pet, honey.
I will, mom. After I finish talking to-
(still smiling strangely) Dean.
--Dean. Annie shrugs, exits. Hogarth looks at Dean curiously.
I found your pet.
Where?
(maintaining clenched smile) Up my leg, man. Squirrel's in my pants, Hogarth. I'm tryin' not to wig out here.
Don't wig out.

(quietly, skin crawling) Okay... he's heading north. (finally) I'm sorry, kid... Dean stands spastically, again addresses the room.  DEAN (CONT’D) I'd like to apologize to everyone in advance for this. He unzips his fly and out pops the squirrel. There is a collective GASP, then a series of shrieks as the squirrel scampers around the diner. Dean zips up and sits back dow DEAN (CONT’D) Check, please. Annie GLARES at a sheepish Hogarth.
Kent now holds a clipboard, taking notes as he talks to a OLD FARMER. Nearby stands a tractor with a bite taken out of it.
And did you see any strange lights in the sky last night? Any saucer- shaped flying objects?
No...
Were any of your live stock disoriented this morning? Did your cows appear anxious or depressed?
No... (getting suspicious) ...who did you say you worked for again? Kent puffs himself up a little bit.

Frankly I'm not at liberty to reveal the particulars of the agency I work for. He leans in confidentially. KENT (CONT’D) But between you and me, I represent the United States Government. U.P.D. The Unexplained Phenomena Department. The Farmer also leans in confidentially.  13.
Huh? Oh, uh... no. Our scope is less limited than the CIA. Unexplained Phenomena, my friend -- that could be anything.
You work out of the Pentagon, then?
Well, sure, we work near the Pentagon, yes. You know Radcliffe Street?
No.
Well, trust me, it's pretty much Pentagon adjacent. And all that that implies.
So, what do you think got to my tractor? Something the commies built? Some kind of monster? Something from outer space? Kent thinks for a moment, then deflates a little.

No, it's probably something else. (sighs wearily) It's always something else. He makes a note on his clipboard. In the background, Dean approaches and hooks up the tractor to his tow truck and hauls it away.
Hogarth comes home. The phone RINGS, and he picks it up.
(automatic, without inflection) Hello this is Hogarth Hughes speaking who's calling please.  14.
Hogarth, honey... I'm really sorry, but I need to work late tonight. There's some cold chicken in the ice box. You can have that and some carrots--
I'm already on it, Mom. He pulls a box of twinkies from a cupboard.
Good. I'll make it up to you, okay?
Okay.
I love you honey. And Hogarth? No scary movies, no late snacks, in bed by eight. Got it?
Got it. cur TO:
is at 8:47... lit up by the ghostly flickering light of t television. We hear CREEPY MUSIC filtered through the tin t.v. speaker. CAMERA DRIFTS to:

... taking a TWINKIE from a package. He SHAKES up a can of whipped cream, jams it into the flat side of the Twinkie, INFLATING it with additional whipped cream. He CRAMS the twinkie in into his mouth, never taking his eyes off the screen.

Lit by the light of a black and white TV, Hogarth has mov furniture and piled up cushions, making a TV watching fortress. There's a NOISE OUTSIDE. Hogarth jumps. Listens. Must have been the TV.  15. ON the TV, a scientist and his assistant are involved in some kind of drama that includes a murderous brain. ANOTHER NOISE OUTSIDE, louder this time. Hogarth freezes: that didn't come from the TV.... ROAR! The TV screen goes white with DEAFENING STATIC.

No! Not now! He SMACKS the TV: no effect. He cranks the big channel knob: THUNK-THUNK-THUNK. All channels are static. HOGARTH (CONT’D) Stupid antenna...! Hogarth stares at the screen, gathers his nerve. He hefts his flashlight and warily heads upstairs.

Hogarth peers out. All quiet, just a WHISPER of wind. He crawls out onto the roof, his flashlight beam follows the flat TV wire up the roof toward its peak... and stops: th antenna is gone, literally torn off the roof!

Gone. Now Hogarth pauses and cocks his head, listening. In the distance he hears a heavy "BOOM." And then another. He peers off into the woods. In the distance he seems to see something moving, just above the level of the trees. Something enormous. HOGARTH (CONT’D) Whoa...
Hogarth hurriedly equips himself: he tapes a flashlight o a toy BB-gun; puts on a football helmet. Finally, he look in the mirror and salutes himself.
Hogarth Hughes. Ready for action.

Hogarth hurries out, runs up to the first massive depress in the grass. Hogarth places his tiny foot beside the car size depression, and very nearly loses his nerve.  16. He takes a deep breath and hurries into the woods.

A dark night, fog drifts through trees. Spooky. At the forest's edge, Hogarth looks up, sees broken branches whe something entered the woods... something big. Hogarth darts from bush to bush, follows the trail. TIME DISSOLVE: Hogarth creeps on, the forest is now dense More and more, the tree-damage begins to take shape, a ta tunnel formed by broken limbs, until... Hogarth GASPS: the tunnel forms a perfect outline of a HU man-shaped THING. He SHIVERS, considers turning back... b he can't. He creeps on. Hogarth hears a deep RHYTMIC HUMMING that VIBRATES the ground. It sounds strange... alien. He creeps on.

The HUMMING is LOUD. Hogarth slowly parts bushes to see.. a power station: "DANGER - HIGH VOLTAGE". Tall power line towers march through the woods. SPARKS SNAP. THUMP! A giant metal foot SLAMS into the ground right in front of Hogarth, he YELPS. THUMP! THUMP! THUMP! ‘Two huge feet become two huge legs. Hogarth looks up, up... A GIANT. Made of metal! Forty feet tall, maybe fifty! Hogarth can't believe his eyes... The giant stares at the metal towers, makes a METALLIC GR that sounds... hungry. It reaches out and SNAPS off a thi piece of metal, pops it in his mouth, CHEWS NOISILY, and SWALLOWS. BURP. Mmmm good!

Wow... it eats metal. Cool. Hogarth sits, hidden in the bushes, and watches, fascinat as the giant "grazes" the metal towers. SPARKS fly from n loose flailing powerlines. The giant's eaten all the tower arms: he TUGS at a solid metal base: it's stuck. So the giant bends down to EAT hi way down the tall metal tower: CHOMP CHOMP CHOMP. Hogarth realizes the giant is CHOMPING toward a mass of thick power cables that HUMM and SPARK.  17.

Annie grabs a flashlight by the door, illuminates the living room... what a mess! And... no Hogarth. KA-ZAPPP! Electricity races up and down the giant's metal it jerks, flies backward, trailing SPARKING POWERLINES th wrap around him as he stumbles into a tangle of more powe lines: KA-ZAP! It panics, flailing, SCREECHING, tries to free itself, gets more entangled. Annie searches through the house by flashlight, for her s becoming more and more frantic.

Hogarth...? Hogarth! HOGARTH!! SPARKS SNAP AND FLY as the giant SHRIEKS in agony. A towe totters and falls... smashing into the ground just as Hogarth jumps clear. Electricity arcs up and down the Giant's body. The giant ROARS, an AWFUL METAL SOUND, falls to its knees, eyes SPARKING, SHORTING OUT. Hogarth looks around, desperate: he's got to save him! He sees a panel: "EMERGENCY CUT-OFF SWITCH". Hogarth runs toward it, sparks raining all around him. He grabs the panel... locked. He swings his BB-gun like a club: CRASH! The gun breaks, the panel door pops open. Hogarth grabs t huge switch and throws all his weight against it. CLUNK. The SPARKS slowly die away.

The dazed giant, looks around, dizzy... he stands, sways, easily SNAPS free of the wires holding him. His eyes focu down (way down) on Hogarth. The boy and the Giant stare a each other for a long time. Now what?
(CALLING) Hogarth! Hogarth turns: down the hill, through the fog, he sees a light floating through the trees.

Mom!  18. Hogarth runs down the hill towards the light... then stop turns back toward the giant.... ...but back where the giant stood, seconds before, is now only dangling SPARKLING power lines. He's gone. Hogarth stares: baffled. Annie rushes up.
Hogarth! She grabs him by his shoulders, tightly, more out of fear than anger.
What do you think you're doing?!! Don't you know better than to wander off at night, alone?? What if something happened to you???
I'm sorry, mom... Annie throws her arms around him, hugging him tight, desperately happy to know that her boy is safe.
Don't ever do that to me again, Hogarth. I was so scared, I thought I'd lost you... A long moment passes with Annie just holding him and rocking... then--
(softly) Mom, you won't believe it. Some- thing ate our t.v. antenna.
Oh, Hogarth...
No, I'm serious! And I went out to see what it was--
(losing patience) Hogarth... please...
--and it was a Giant metal--  19.
HOGARTH! Stop it! I'm not in the mood. (gentle, but firm) Come on. Let's go home.

Hogarth sits in silence as Annie starts the ignition. As they drive away, Hogarth can't help but look back over hi shoulder. Backlit by the moon, he can just make out the outline of the Giant, half-hidden by the trees... watchin them go...
The North Maine woods, the trees sway, holding their secr deep within.
The TEACHER is quizzing her students. Hogarth is the smallest one in the class. On the chalkboard are written the words "RUSSIA" and "POLAND."

And who can name another country that is part of the U.S.S.R.? Hogarth raises his hand. TEACHER (CONT’D) Anyone besides Hogarth? Hogarth lowers his hand. No response from the others. TEACHER (CONT’D) Anyone actually listening to me other than Hogarth? Hogarth, are we going to have to move you up another grade? Or should we move the rest of the class down? Alright, that's it. Everyone in the class except Hogarth can write me a five page essay. Call it "Allies and Enemies of the United States of America." It's due tomorrow. The class groans. A big kid turns around to Hogarth, poin at him, and gives him the "slit throat" sign. Hogarth WIL  20.
Workers swarm over the towers, repairing the damage. Kent is there, smoking a pipe as he talks to a foreman.
Yeah, sometimes a line'll snap if the weather's bad, sure. But fora whole tower to get twisted up like that? (SCRATCHES HIS HEAD) I tell you, it's got me beat.
And not a single witness...
'Fraid not, sir.
Could this have been caused by a giant metal monster, perhaps?
Pardon me, sir?
Nothing. Just repeating a yarn I heard from some fishermen... Just then, something catches Kent's eye.

Excuse me. He walks a few steps away, and hunkers down beside a port of the rubble. A trapezoidal piece of wood is sticking ou from beneath it. Kent pulls it out. It's the handle of a B.B. gun. On Kent's look we cut to...

Students pour out of Hogarth's classroom, followed at las by Hogarth, who is a full head smaller than any of them. Now Hogarth's face brightens, as a few kids his size pass by. Hogarth hurries to catch up with them.
Hey guys! The kids turn to Hogarth without much enthusiasm.
Hey, Hogarth.  21.
Listen, you're not going to believe what happened to me last night. I went walking into the forest, and I saw this... giant! The kids exchange glances.
It was made out of metal! And it tore apart the power station. For a moment, the kids stare at Hogarth blankly. Finally, one of them speaks.
You know what I just remembered? I'm suppose to help some people do some stuff way over in some other place right now.
Oh those people? Yeah, I'm suppose to do that too.
Nice seeing you, Hogarth. As the kids walk away, Hogarth hears one of them speak quietly to the other. FIRST KID (CONT’D) Boy, I hope they never skip me a grade.
He's gotten really desperate. A determined look comes over Hogarth's face we cut to...
Hogarth marches purposefully into the forest with a camer slung over his shoulder, and a sheet of metal in one hand
Hellllllooo! Come ouuut!
The woods are denser now, with shafts of autumn sun punctuating the darkened light. Hogarth bangs the metal loudly as he walks.
Hey, big metal guy!! It's me, the kid who turned off the power for ya!
Hogarth sets the metal down, then retreats a safe distance...

Metal! Delicious metal! Come and get it! ...and settles in behind a large log. He aims the camera, and waits. And waits. And waits. This is clearly not as exciting as Hogarth expected. He rubs his eyes, yawns, and lays his head on h arm. And the next thing he knows, he's waking up. The afternoo light has given way to the long shadows of early evening. Hogarth looks towards the clearing -- the piece of metal gone. He gasps. He reaches behind him for the camera, as he scans the forest, left and right. Suddenly he pauses. His hand is n finding the camera. He turns and looks for it. It's gone. Above him a flashbulb pops. A moment later, a roll of fil drops from the sky and lands at his feet. Hogarth picks u the film, and swallows hard. He looks up, a long way up, sees the Giant standing over him, its jaw moving, and a crunching sound coming from its mouth. HOGARTH (CONT’D) Aaaaagh! Hogarth runs as fast as his legs will carry him. He cover twenty feet or so, when -- BOOM! An enormous metal foot touches down in front of him. He runs faster, faster, but with a single step, the Giant covers all the distance between them.  23. Suddenly -- WHACK! Hogarth catches a tree limb across the chin, and is sent sprawling to the ground. The Giant loom over him. Hogarth sits up, his eyes wide with fear, and shouts at the fifty-foot metal monster. HOGARTH (CONT’D) What do you want from me?!! The Giant sits down with a thud. Then he reaches toward Hogarth with a closed fist, turns it palm-upward and open his fingers. There, in his hand, is the four-foot metal handle with "EMERGENCY SHUT-OFF" printed along its length HOGARTH (CONT’D) The shut-off switch... Hogarth looks from the handle to the Giant, in awe. HOGARTH (CONT’D) You saw me save you. As boy and Giant stare into each other's eyes, we cut to.
Some of the BUSYBODIES sit around sipping coffee and gossiping.
Well, in my opinion, it's a woman's obligation to re-marry. If not for herself, than for her child. The Busybodies murmur their assent.

Do you know she left her little boy all alone last night? My son heard he went wandering around all by himself. Near the power plant... At the mention of this word, a figure at a nearby booth lowers his newspaper, and narrows his eyes. It's Kent.
Tsk-tsk. On the very night those power lines came down? The poor child could have been killed. The Busybodies gasp in shock and disapproval.  24.
It just goes to prove my point. She ought to provide him with a father figure, if she cares about the boy.
She does care about her boy, for your information. Annie enters, tying on an apron. The Busybodies blush and fan themselves nervously.
And she thanks you so much for your concern. (then wearily) More coffee, anyone?

I'd love some. Annie turns. Kent gives her his best smile. Annie pours coffee, we see Kent studying her with a thoughtful, almos sinister look. He glances at her name tag. KENT (CONT’D) Annie. What a very lovely name... Annie smiles.
The Giant and Hogarth sit facing each other, each staring the other with curiosity.
So... what are you? The Giant tilts his head curiously but says nothing. HOGARTH (CONT’D) Do you talk? The Giant continues staring, puzzled.

"Talk." You know, words? "Blah- blah- blah," like that. Can you do that -- "Blah-blah-blah?" The Giant opens and closes his mouth in imitation of Hogarth. A series of deep metallic rumblings and clanging come out of his mouth.  25. HOGARTH (CONT’D) Well, you get the concept, anyway. But we need to work on your vocabulary. Let's see. Hogarth looks around, sees a rock, and picks it up. HOGARTH (CONT’D) See this? This is called a rock. "Rock." Try it. "Rooock."
Kraaan-chunk.
"Rooock."
Kroooonk.
(patiently) Rock.
Rog.
Good! See? This is a... rock. A look of dawning understanding comes over the Giant. He looks at the rock in Hogarth's hand.
Rog. He picks up a nearby boulder.
Rog?
Yes! The Giant pulls a tree out of the ground.
Rog!
No, no. That is a tree. Tree. (POINTS AT ROCK) Rock. (POINTS AT TREE) Treeeee.  26. The Giant's mouth hangs open in awe.
Rog... Treeee-(SOUND OF A TRUCK
Get it? Everything has a different name. Rock. Tree... The giant's mouth hangs open in awe...
A very tired Hogarth is still seated (uncomfortably now) front of a still awe-struck Giant. The Giant picks up a piece of wood.
(tired) Branch.
Braaannch. The Giant picks up another piece of wood.
Yeah, that's a branch, too.
Braaannch. (picks up a rock) Rog?

Look, we've pretty much covered everything in the forest. And if I don't get home soon, mom's gonna wonder where I am. (gets on his feet) You stay here, okay? I'll come back tomorrow. Hogarth waves to the Giant and EXITS. Now Hogarth hears a BOOM behind him. He turns to see the Giant following him. HOGARTH (CONT’D) And don't follow me, either.  27. The Giant continues following, happily.
I said don't. Don't follow me. Stay. Go home. I mean it!
A fog is settling in, as Hogarth leaves the forest and crosses a set of railroad tracks. He points to the house the bottom of the hill.
Look. That's where I live, okay? I'm going there, and you're not, understand? So goodbye. Hey... He turns to see the Giant kneeling curiously beside the railroad tracks. He pokes at them.
(HUNGRY SOUND)
Hey, wait a minute-- Too late. The Giant bites down on the twin strands of railroad track and rips them loose like spaghetti.

head_text.subj: WHAT DO YOU THINK YOU'RE DOING

text: The Giant freezes, puzzled, long strings of railroad trac dangling from his month.

Put them back! Now the Giant looks confused and guilty. DING DING DING! The crossing signal blares, red lights flash. The Giant stares at the pretty lights, entranced. Hogarth GASPS, looks down the tracks. He hears a distant whistle blow: WOO-WOOO.

Oh no... .(HE RUNS TO THE GIANT) Put them back RIGHT NOW!!! The Giant stares, puzzled. Hogarth GROANS, runs to a piec of track sticking up and pushes down on it with all his weight... it doesn't budge.  28.
Like this. Help me! The Giant sees Hogarth struggling with the curled tracks, takes one index finger, and helpfully pushes on them: KA- BLAM! They're down.
Good! That's it! The Giant grunts, pleased with himself... Hogarth HEARS t train, close now. And then he sees-- the pieces of track don't meet up.

Put them together! Like this! Hogarth pantomimes. The Giant lines up one track-- HOGARTH (CONT’D) Now the other one... hurry! -- then tries to line up the other side, but it's tricky, the two chewed-on rails stubbornly resist lining up. Finally, the giant gets them close. HOGARTH (CONT’D) Good enough! Come on! Hogarth takes off, racing like the wind to get out of the He STOPS, looks back...
is still fussing with the tracks, trying to get them perfect.

No! Come on! The train's coming! The Giant is intent on his puzzle: CLICK. CLICK. Almost. Now we see the headlight of a big freight train coming ou of the fog. The Giant continues to fuss. HOGARTH (CONT’D) The train! The Giant finally SNAPS the track into place. CLICK. He grins. A train whistle SHRIEKS! The startled Giant looks as Hogarth hits the dirt and--
Kent examines the broken branches. Hears the BOOM of the train wreck.

Steam flies. The EXPLOSION dies away. Hogarth looks up. The Giant is gone. The train, its front end smashed, coas down the track, breaks squealing. Hogarth looks around... Then, THUMP! The Giant's head lands beside him. An arm falls here, a leg there. A hand flies down the hil toward Hogarth's house.
Oh no... Hogarth sees the giant lying around in big pieces. He touches the Giant's hand gently, a look of pain and sadne on his face. HOGARTH (CONT’D) (WHIMPERS )

And then, behind him, the Giant's head, still attached to its torso, sits up. Hogarth YELPS. The Giant's eyes spark, flash and click on. He looks around, dazed, at his scattered parts. HOGARTH (CONT’D) You're alive! The torso has one leg and most of one arm attached. The other pieces seem to come alive and scamper around as if confused. An antenna rises out of the top of the Giant's head and begins to "signal". All the pieces SNAP to attention. They crawl toward the Giant, who gathers them in his arm and looks at Hogarth, confused. Just then we h voices coming from the fog.
Hello? Is anyone out there? Are you alright? Hogarth squints into the fog.

The train Conductor. Oh, we're in trouble now...  30. HOGARTH (CONT’D) (turns to Giant) Okay, look. I've changed my mind. You can follow me home. He hurries off down the hill, with the one-legged Giant hopping along behind him.
Hogarth enters the barn, with the hopping Giant behind hi

You can stay here for now. The Giant takes a seat and sets his body parts down besid him. The Giant's arm parts dutifully line up, the arm fir He picks it up and jams it into its socket. HOGARTH (CONT’D) And try to keep it quiet okay? My mom's not too big on me having any pets right now. "Shhhh" -- get it?
The train ENGINEER and a CONDUCTOR are examining the trac in the swirling fog.
Whatever we hit, it was something big. A tractor, maybe.
More like a tank, I'd say.
So where the heck did it go? Out of the fog comes Kent, pipe in hand. He casts a glanc at the Conductor and the Engineer, then turns and looks d the hill towards Hogarth's house.
Annie enters from the kitchen, wiping her hands on her apron.
Dinner's been on the table for twenty minutes now. Where have you been all afternoon?  31.
I could tell you, Mom. But I really don't think you'd believe me.
Somehow, I don't doubt that.
The Giant finishes attaching his leg, and is now all together save for a missing HAND. He looks around the bar for it.
Annie and Hogarth sit at the dinner table.
Would you say grace, please? Hogarth folds his hands together, and starts to bow his h when he STOPS: behind Annie, the Giant's hand crawls acro the kitchen floor like a tarantula.
Annie looks up. Hogarth rolls his eyes to heaven.
Oh my God, we thank you for the... uh, food that Mom has put in front of us and--
Hogarth jumps up. The curious hand-- now standing up on t fingers and reaching for an antique vase-- reacts to Hogarth's tone and shrinks back. Hogarth sees Annie stari at him. Again, he covers --
-the Devil from doing bad things... and-- (TO HAND)
GET OUTTA HERE!...uh, Satan. GO! GO! So that we may live in peace. Amen.
Amen. That was... (words fail her) ...really unusual, Hogarth.  32.
(leaps to his feet) Gotta use the bathroom.
Well... (HE'S ALREADY GONE) Okay.

Hogarth runs up to the hand, blocking it from going to th cellar. He takes one of the enormous fingers with both hands, and leads it like a baby elephant to the front doo He opens the door revealing-- --KENT, startled, about to knock. He smiles his most charming smile. Hogarth GASPS, SLAMS the door. He breathe hard, panicking. But when he turns around, the hand is GONE. The doorbell RINGS. Not knowing what to do, Hogarth opens it. Kent's still there, smiling, as before.
Hey there, Scout... Kent Mansley. I work for the government. Your parents home?
We're eating.
What's wrong, Scout? You seem a little jumpy.
Who is it, Hogarth? Annie has entered the living room. Kent REACTS.
Why, hello there! Annie, isn't it? From the diner?
That's right! Mr. Mansley?
Please. Call me Kent. (wheels turning) So this is your house... (to Hogarth) ...then you must be Hobo!  33.
Hogarth.
Hobart.

Yes indeed. I'm terribly sorry to bother you at this hour, but I'm looking into a little train accident that happened nearby and-- my goodness! Is there a blue- ribbon pie in the oven, or have I died and gone to Heaven?
(smiles) We've just sat down to dinner, Mr. Mansley. Would you care to join us?

If it's not too much trouble, I'd be delighted! He flashes her a thousand-dollar smile. As Annie turns he back to lead them into the dining room, Kent's smile fade into a calculating look. Hogarth sees it all, and glares as Kent walks past him. Kent doffs his hat, places it over Hogarth's head as he advances into the living room.
Here. Pretend you're a gangster. The hat covers Hogarth's head. He stands there, looking ridiculous.
Hogarth, Annie and Kent are seated at the dinner table. Kent is pouring on the charm to Annie, as Hogarth continu to eye him suspiciously. Kent pats his stomach.
Well! It certainly is true what they say; the hospitality in these parts is second to none.  34.
Which parts would those be, sir?
Well, you know, uh... Maine.
I never heard anyone say that about Maine. Have you, Mom?
Hogarth...
Oh, it's alright. He's a bright boy. I like bright boys... He lights his pipe and studies Hogarth closely.
So tell me, Hogarth. What do you think of all the goings-on around here lately? Hogarth plays innocent.
Goings-on?
You know, the power plant being destroyed and all.
Careful, Mr. Mansley... he's got a powerful imagination.
Please. Call me Kent. I like to be on a first-name basis with first- class chefs. Annie smiles. Hogarth rolls his eyes.
If it's alright with everybody, I think I'll be excused now.

But you haven't answered my question, Hogarth. Kent leans in toward Hogarth menacingly.  35. KENT (CONT’D) The powerplant. (leans closer) The train. (even closer) Surely you must have a theory, Hogarth. A bright boy like you. Surely you must have an inkling --
(blurting it out) There's a monster out there!
What???
It's a hideous creature, five stories tall, and if you go out looking for it you won't come back alive! There's a moment of stunned silence. Then...
You're... kidding.
Of course he's kidding.
(shrugs) I'm a kid. That's what we do. Suddenly, a toilet flushes upstairs. A puzzled expression comes over Hogarth's face, then Annie's, then Kent's.
Do you have a guest?
No... Hogarth leaps from his seat and dashes out of the room. Kent raises an eyebrow. Annie looks puzzled.

Hogarth yanks open the door, revealing: The giant hand, which crouches on the sink as it unrolls pile of toilet paper into a pile on the floor.  36. Hogarth shuts the door behind him, startling the hand, wh leaps to the floor with a THUD!
Kent and Annie react to the sound, and stare at the ceili
Excuse me. She exits.
Hogarth labors as he pulls the giant hand toward the open window. The hand resists mildly, like a distracted child-
Annie stands outside the door. She knocks.
Hogarth? Are you alright?
Kent turns his attention to the sounds coming from upstai He exits.
Using his whole body, Hogarth tries to shove the giant ha out the open window.
(GRUNTING SOUNDS)
Kent has joined Annie, and the two of them listen togethe
(LOUDER GRUNTING)
This sort of thing is why it's so important to really chew your food... Annie shoots Kent a disapproving look.  37.
With a mighty shove, he finally manages to get the hand o the window.
--rrrrrgggggghhhhh! The hand lands with a terrific crash, Hogarth tumbles to ground, and Annie and Kent burst in through the door to
Hogarth... sheepishly standing there in a large PILE of unrolled toilet paper.

Good lord, you've been acting strange lately. Kent looks from Hogarth to the open window. In the darkne outside, he seems to see a shadowy figure moving in the dark. He turns to Annie, and gives her his patented smile
Do you have a telephone I could use?
Kent, hunkered into a corner in an attempt at privacy, speaks into a telephone in a loud whisper. Kent peers around cautiously, making sure he's not observed.
--let me put it bluntly, sir. I'm onto something big in Rockwell, Maine.
(tired) What is it this time, Kent?
This time -- well, this time it's a giant, that's roaming around the town destroying things.
Uh-huh. Well, you be sure to file us a report, and we'll be sure to process it.  38.
Excellent, sir. And in the meantime, I'd like to call in my team.
Your... team?
My backup, my support squad. Half a dozen men are all I need to start...
Kent, I know this will come as a shock to you, but we can't just give a team to anyone who asks.
(puffing himself up) Forgive my saying so, sir, but I'm not just anyone, and I've never asked. Before. Until now. (there is a long silence) Sir?
You haven't really found something, have you?
I think I have, sir, yes.
You think. Do you have proof?
Sir, I've got a feeling about this one, a gut feeling...
That's lovely, Kent. But let me try to explain how this works. If you called to tell me you'd found, say, a giant footprint, I might send over an expert to make a plaster cast of it. If you saw an
actual giant with your own eyes, I might even send you the team you're asking for. Heck, you go so far as to get me a photograph, I could probably get the U.S. (MORE )
Army over there to Rockwell, Maine. But you tell me you've got a feeling--
(temper rising) Alright then, fine. You want evidence? I'll get your evidence...
(TIRED) That sounds swell, Kent.

And when I do, I'm going to want a memo distributed! And I'm going to want that memo carbon copied and -- and re-distributed and -- The Chief hangs up. As Kent stands with the phone receive in his hand, a look of dark determination comes over his face. And then we pan up through the ceiling above Kent, into Hogarth's room. Hogarth also holds a phone receiver, with one hand cupped over the mouthpiece. He looks worried.
Annie says goodbye to Hogarth at the front door.
Bye, Honey! Have a good day at school.
(WAVING) Bye, Mom. Hogarth pedals his bike away until he's out of sight of t front house, then zips around the side of the house, ditc his bike and grabs a little red wagon.
Hogarth pulls the wagon around, collecting metal. He find some cans, an old car muffler, a fallen street sign, etc.
Hogarth enters and finds the Giant sleeping.
Ahem...  40. The Giant opens his eyes. He sees the wagon full of metal and looks delighted.
(HUNGRY SOUND)

It wasn't easy to fill this wagon. So try to not to eat it all at once- The Giant picks the wagon up, and dumps its entire conten into his mouth. Hogarth is speechless. HOGARTH (CONT’D) Do you have any idea what it took to find that metal??? I scoured the neighborhood! I had to ditch school! I've never done that before, I-- The Giant picks up the wagon and eats that too. Hogarth sighs and takes a seat. HOGARTH (CONT’D) So... now that we've eaten, how shall we spend the rest of our day? The Giant looks at him, not understanding. HOGARTH (CONT’D) Okay. I'll teach you more words. Hogarth stands up and points at his house. HOGARTH (CONT’D) That is my "home." That's where I come from . My... (points at himself) home... Hogarth points to his house. The Giant looks at it.

Right. Now where is... (points at giant) ...your home?  The Giant 41. looks at Hogarth's house, then follows Hogarth's pointing hand, and looks at himself. Then a look of deep sadness comes over his face. His shoulders shrug, and his hands turn palm-upward in a puzzled gesture.
You mean... you don't know where you came from?

Wow. You poor guy... Now we hear a deep rumbling sound. The Giant looks down a his stomach hungrily. The Giant He points HOGARTH (CONT’D) I know, I know. (thinks for a moment) Okay, I know a place where it's all you can eat. But not until after dark. stares at him, uncomprehending. HOGARTH (CONT’D) Let me put it this way. at through the window at the sun.
"Sun."
"Suuughn."
When the sun goes down... Hogarth mimes the sun arcing down the sky to sunset. The taps on the Giant's iron belly. HOGARTH (CONT’D) Feeding time. Get it?
(COMPREHENDING SOUND)
Good! Hogarth starts to leave, then pauses and turns back to lo at the Giant. HOGARTH (CONT’D) You're smarter than you look, aren't you?
(puzzled sound)
(exiting) Never mind.
In a time-lapse, we see the sun arc across the sky and se over picturesque Rockwell, Maine.
Two silhouettes creep into the night -- one small, one enormous.
A ways off, Hogarth relaxes.
Come on. Let's go! Hogarth starts walking. The Giant moves past him- BOOM BO BOOM! -and with a half dozen strides, is almost out of sight.

On the horizon, the giant turns, looks puzzled: now what? HOGARTH (CONT’D) Not that fast! Sheesh! Come back here! BOOM! BOOM! BOOM! In two seconds, the giant stands at Hogarth's side and looks down at him, confused. HOGARTH (CONT’D) Pick me up, OK?  43. The giant does as he's told, lowers his huge hand to the ground. Hogarth climbs up on it. The giant carefully raises up his hand, with Hogarth on it. Hogarth grabs ont a finger, and points toward the northwest. HOGARTH (CONT’D) Okay, now. March! Hogarth hangs on for dear life as the giant quickly accelerates. Hogarth looks down, and GASPS: they're reall moving!
Kent is hunting around the power plant with a flashlight, muttering to himself.
(scornful) "Evidence". I'll get your evidence... He scans the vast expanse of forest with his flashlight, sags hopelessly.
...somewhere...
Hogarth and the Giant are marching along a back road on t hills outside town.
It's like a magic carpet ride, as the moon-lit countrysid below sails past his vantage point, fifty feet above the ground. Hogarth points at a church steeple.
Church. Churrrch.
Churrr-(CRUNCH)
Yes. People pray there. (points at another building) School. Can you say that? Schooool...
Skooo...
Schooool suuuucks...
Skoooo saauuugz...
Very good. And that's all you need to know about school.
Kent has wandered some distance from the power plant now. His flashlight beam sweeps across the ground.

Nothing. Nothing... Just then, he hears a noise behind him. He stops. Wheels around -- and the beam of his flashlight catches-- --a MOOSE. Huge. Enormous antlers. Looking right at him. moose SNORTS. Kent backpedals, stumbles backward into a ditch- KENT (CONT’D) Whooooa! --loudly enough to scare off the moose. He gets up, dusts himself off, shines his flashlight around and discovers w he's standing in is not a ditch at all, but a-- GIANT FOOTPRINT, perfectly preserved in a patch of dried mud. Kent GASPS. The gasp becomes a sound of delight. He begin to laugh... And then a single rain drop falls on head. Kent looks up. Another drop falls. The laughter ceases.
Hogarth is still riding on the Giant's shoulder. Rain has begun to drizzle down now.
And that building there is the coffee shop.
Kau-(CLANG) shawww...  He raises The Giant 45.
That's where my mom works. Sometimes she has to stay late, to make extra money ‘cause... well, my Dad's away. You know what a "dad" is? A "father?"
"Pa-grrr?"

Yeah. It's like me... (points at himself) Only bigger. a hand indicating somone taller. HOGARTH (CONT’D) He used to take me to baseball games. This one time, we brought binoculars, and we tried to figure out what pitch the catcher was calling! One year we want to go to every home game! I mean-- we wanted to... stops walking and swivels his enormous head to face Hogarth. For a moment, they stare at each other in silence, with the rain pouring down around them. Then Hogarth bursts out, almost angrily. The Giant The Giant HOGARTH (CONT’D) Aw, what am I even talking to you for? You can't understand a word I'm saying! continues staring. HOGARTH (CONT’D) Can you? speaks --and somewhere within the metal clanging of his voice, there seems to be a note of sympathetic sadness.
"Fa-grrrr." Hogarth sighs, and pats the Giant on the side of the head
Well, I guess it's better than talking to myself.  46. The Giant looks pleased by this. They continue on their way.
Kent, soaked to the bone, is sitting on the edge of the Giant footprint, which has become a soggy, nondescript me

God hates me... He pulls out his pipe, and tries to light it, but his sog matches won't strike. KENT (CONT’D) Damnation! (shouting heavenward) Can't a guy get a break around here?!! Suddenly the rain lets up. Kent looks surprised. Then pleased. He lights his pipe. Then turns to heaven again. KENT (CONT’D) Thank you. Waaagh! He does a huge double take as he looks up to see the Gian smiling head looming above him. The Giant picks up Kent's metal flashlight, eats it, and in three strides is gone f sight, leaving the terrified and exhilarated Kent behind. UNDER THE GIANT'S CHIN... ...Hogarth PEEKS OUT, breathing hard.
That can't be good.
A metal graveyard, sprawling as far as the eye can see.

This is it. The Giant's metal hand sets Hogarth down into frame. HOGARTH (CONT’D) All you can eat. The Giant surveys the metal in all directions: MOANING happily as he spies a huge stack of cars. He selects one, and slowly... carefully... bites into it...  47.
(DELIGHTED SOUND)
He selects another car, picks it up and bites into it like a gourmand tasting a fine chocolate.
Mmmm... He tastes another.
Ooooooh... --causing the CAR HORN TO BLAST!

SHHHH!! Turn it off, turn it OFF!!! The giant looks around nervously, helplessly, beginning t PANIC. He tries shaking it, then sitting on it... but nothing works; the horn is STUCK. Hogarth looks back toward the house--

head_text.subj: AT THE FAR END OF THE JUNKYARD

text: A light goes on in a little house. Finally, the Giant takes a monster chomp and snaps the ca in half. The horn strangles into silence.
Dean reaches the door, opens it: a GASPING, out-of-breath Hogarth stands on his doorstep. Dean studies Hogarth for moment. Then breaks into a smile.
Hey, I know you. Squirrel boy.
Hogarth.
By night known as Hogarth. Got it. Well, come inside kid. Hell, it's raining out there, isn't it?
Jazz is playing on the hi-fi of this distinctly bohemian pad. Dean presses an espresso.  48.
Listen, you're not going to call my mom are you? She doesn't know I'm out. I could get in trouble.

Don't worry, kid. It's not my style to report a guy to the authorities. He brings over two espresso cups and hands one to Hogarth DEAN (CONT’D) Espresso for me, Bosco for you. But I thought you'd dig the little cup. Hogarth looks pleased.
Thanks.
My name's Dean. I'm a nobody. And you are...?
Hogarth. I'm... kind of a nobody, too.
So what brings you all the way up here, Hogarth? You riding some kind of crazy inspiration?
I've been riding something alright... The record finishes, and in the silence: LOUD CRUNCHING NOISES from outside. Dean jumps up.
Did you hear that??? He grabs a crowbar, runs to the door; Hogarth jumps up.
No, wait! Stop!
The door flies open, Dean leaps out, YELLS:
Who's out there?! He hears a metallic GASP. He looks up, up, up and sees th gargantuan Giant, tailpipes sticking out of his mouth, frozen, a guilty "caught!" look on its face. Dean YELPS..
--my god! RUN KID, RUN!!!!

(rolls his eyes) It's OK...! But the heroic Dean seizes Hogarth and turns to duck insi --which the giant immediately interprets as a threat and- --SLAMS his massive hand in front of the door, blocking i as Hogarth tries to break free of Dean, to explain-- HOGARTH (CONT’D) The giant isn't--let GO! as the giant GRABS DEAN, hoisting him high in the air.
The giant STOPS--looks down at Hogarth, puzzled. HOGARTH (CONT’D) ...Squash.... him. Good boy. (beat, heavy sigh, then-) His name is Dean. We like Dean. Dean good. Put him down.
Dean. The giant grins at Dean; he sways, shocked, overwhelmed.
Dean, meet a friend of mine. Dean, giant. Giant, Dean. The giant grins, and kind of "waves". Dean stands there, pale, completely overwhelmed. HOGARTH (CONT’D) More coffee...?  50.
Dean stares, stunned, at the huge, impassive giant.
So... where'd he come from?
He doesn't remember. He's like a little kid...
Little. (mirthless laugh) Yeah. Huh.
He needs food. And shelter. Dean stares at Hogarth in expressionless shock. Then slow stands, pours out his coffee, goes inside, locking the do behind him.
The blinds have been pulled. Hogarth stands at the Dean's front door, pleading.
You got plenty of room here! This place is perfect!
(from inside, muffled) Go away.
I can have him push the door down. You know I can. Pause. The door opens and there's Dean, looking annoyed.
Hogarth! I can't hide it here!
Him. Not it. Him.
Whatever! You don't even know where he came from! Or what the hell he is!  51.
(stubbornly) He's ...my friend. Dean stares at immovable Hogarth. Behind him, dawn breaks

(low mutter) Yeah. What am I, am I your friend? Bring some frankenbot with out of state plates over here and make me change my tune... don't like that jazz... God, I'm tired... Dean gives up, stands, worn-out, exhausted.
So! He can stay?!
Tonight. Tomorrow, I don't know... (wanders inside, muttering) ...figure something out.... Dean stumbles toward his home. Hogarth grins, and looks a the now-tired giant, YAWNING.
Let's get you tucked in....

Hogarth smiles to himself, as he watches the giant sleep, now covered with a layer of junk, a camouflage-comforter. And then he hears a BEEPING NOISE. Hogarth looks up and sees an ARMY PLANE, flying towards him. The BEEPING gets louder. Hogarth realizes it's coming fro the Giant. Suddenly: WHIR, a panel on the giant's arm slides open. A strange device pops out and starts trackin the plane overhead. Hogarth panics: as the plane comes nearer the BEEPING becomes more insistent, the strange device tracks the pla it looks very retro-advanced and scary. The giant starts MOANING, thrashing in his sleep as if caught in a bad dream. Suddenly he wakes up and ka-CHUK!- the device withdraws. The plane disappears over the trees Hogarth looks at the giant, stunned. The giant, unaware, looks at Hogarth, puzzled.  52.
It's okay. Go back to sleep. It was just a bad dream. The giant nods, comforted, and drops off into sleep. Hogarth walks away, deeply troubled.
Hogarth creeps upstairs to his room, pulls back the cover and is just about to dive in... when Annie enters; spies Hogarth up and dressed.
You're up already? Hogarth tiredly replaces the bedcovers.
...just making the bed....
That's nice. Come downstairs. I have a surprise for you...
An exhausted Hogarth shuffles downstairs, and into the kitchen.
He sits down sleepily at the breakfast table and then GAS sitting across from him, reading the paper and looking qu at home in a fatherly way is --
Kent...?
Morning, sport. Sleep well? He feels Kent's knowing eyes boring into him.
Moooooooom! Annie appears, carrying a plate of waffles. She sets a plate down and leans in towards Hogarth, beaming.
Isn't it wonderful, Hogarth? We finally got a border!  53.
(PANICKED) Oh no... Kent looks at his watch.
You know, I meant to wake up bright and early this morning. But from the look of those waffles, I'm still in bed dreaming!
Oh, Mr. Mansley-- (Kent wags a finger) -- Kent. Kent and Annie share a meaningful look. Hogarth looks ill
Uh... I'm not very hungry. He exits. Kent watches him go, then picks up the fork tha Hogarth was holding, and surreptitiously drops it ina little plastic evidence bag.
Hogarth strolls in and takes a seat at the counter next t man reading a newspaper. A bored waitress approaches.
Chocolate malted, please. (she exits) I've never been in here. Mom says the coffee's weak and they put meat extender in the hamburger.
It ain't the diner, sparky. But it's more private. The man lowers the paper to reveal his face. It's Dean. H glances around cautiously to make sure they're not being watched.
So. Your friend's got quite an appetite.
Yeah. When I found him, he was trying to eat the power station.  54.
So where does he come from?
(shrugs) He doesn't know.
You can talk to him???
Kinda. He can't say a lot of words yet, but he understands things pretty good.
I wonder if he had something to do with the meteorite that splashed down here the other day. Then again, maybe he was the meteorite...
That's what I was thinking! He came from outer space!!
Maybe. Or maybe he was launched into space from earth.
Hey, maybe the commies made him! You know, in one of their secret labs.
Or maybe we built him in one of ours. Our government has secrets, too you know.
(getting into it) Or maybe he comes from underground, you know? Like, he's this undiscovered species, that evolved from minerals or something, while we were evolving out of monkeys.
Maybe, kid. And then, again, maybe the monkeys evolved from us. Dean laughs and puts his hands behind his head, and strik a philosophical pose.  55.
I wish we knew why he was here.
Hey, I wish I knew why I was here. Hogarth puts his hands behind his head and strikes a philosophical pose, too. He seems to be enjoying the adul conversation.
Yeah.
I mean if you think about it, nobody really knows where they came from, why they're here, or where they're going. We believe. We hope. But we don't know.
Right, right...
And some cats, that scares 'em, you know?
You're telling me.
They race around, play the game, chase money, chase power...
Just so they won't have to wonder what life's all about.
Exactly. (beat, suddenly impressed) Hey... Dean lifts his coffee cup, saluting Hogarth. They sit in silence for a moment, happily contemplating the universe.

As Kent looks on, an AGENT in a lab coat studies a spoon now dusted with white powder -- under a microscope.  56. After a moment, he looks up, and gestures at the BB-gun, also dusted with powder, which lies on the table nearby. Agent turns to the man in shadow standing over him.
It's the same fingerprint. A match is struck. We follow it up to the man's pipe, already in his mouth. As the match flares it lights up Kent's face. He smiles diabolically.
Hogarth contentedly slurps the last of his malted through plastic straw. Dean works on a slab of apple pie.
Hey, Dean?
Yeah?
What is life all about? For you, I mean.
For me? Well... (shrugs) I guess I'd like to prove there's something pure in me, you know? They say the soul is part angel and part monster. Sometimes I think life is a chance to set the angel free.
The Giant looks like a monster. But inside he's good. I can tell.

The ROAR of his engines fades into silence as a look of peace falls over his iron face. He wraps his arms around nose of the missile, closing his eyes...  90. ...and slams his fist into the tip of the bomb--
The blackness of the night sky goes brilliant WHITE.

Pieces of the giant rain all over the Eastern Hemisphere, a spectacular display.
